Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story:
I stared at the group chat, my phone buzzing with excitement from my siblings. Mom had planned a big family trip for the weekend, something we hadn’t done in years. Everyone was expected to be there, and I knew how much it meant to my parents and my brothers. As a sister, I wanted to be present, to laugh and make memories with them, especially since we rarely all get together anymore.

But Sunday morning was also the only time I could join the church service, something I’d been missing lately. My faith is important to me, and I felt a growing emptiness from skipping worship and not seeing my church friends. I could almost hear the pastor’s voice, reminding us of the importance of gathering together, of keeping our faith at the center.

The two expectations pulled at me—my family’s joy and togetherness, and my own need for spiritual connection. I felt torn, guilty at the thought of disappointing either side. My heart ached as I tried to figure out how to be both a good sister and a faithful Christian, knowing I couldn’t fully be both at the same time.
